title: 103_s10
content:
The "Flexible Family Leave Tax Credit Act of 1993" is also known as the Family Leave Credit. It amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to create a new section for the Family Leave Credit. The Family Leave Credit allows employers with fewer than 500 employees to claim a 20 percent credit on qualified compensation for employees on family leave. An employer with fewer than 500 employees can claim a 20% credit on qualified compensation for employees on family leave. The amount of qualified compensation per employee is capped at $100 per business day. Family leave credit is not available if the leave exceeds 12 weeks (60 business days) in a 12-month period. Family leave is limited if the employee has unused sick, disability, or similar leave. Family leave is defined as leave for qualified purposes like the birth of a child or adoption/foster care placement. Family leave can be taken for the birth of a child, adoption, foster care, caring for a family member with a serious health condition, or for the employee's own serious health condition. The definition of a child includes various relationships like son, daughter, stepchild, foster child, or legal ward. The term 'serious health condition' refers to an illness, injury, impairment, or physical or mental condition that requires inpatient care in a hospital, hospice, or residential health care facility, or ongoing treatment by a healthcare provider. The family leave credit allows for a refundable credit under certain conditions. The family leave credit is available to employers who provide family leave to employees on a nondiscriminatory basis. The term 'employer' and 'employee' are defined for the purpose of this section. The family leave credit is available to employers who have employed the individual for at least 12 months and provided over 1000 hours of service in the preceding year. Qualified compensation includes cash wages paid during the family leave period. The family leave credit allows employers to pay cash wages based on the employee's average daily cash wages for the preceding four quarters. Business days exclude Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays. This provision ensures employment and benefits protection for eligible employees. The family leave credit provides employment and benefits protection by ensuring that employees are entitled to return to their position or an equivalent one with the same benefits and conditions after taking leave. The family leave credit allows employees to maintain coverage under a group health plan during leave, without requiring accrual of seniority or employment benefits. The family leave credit ensures employees maintain coverage under a group health plan during leave, without losing employment benefits. Employers must reasonably believe the employee will return to work to qualify for the credit. Regulatory authority allows for necessary guidance. The regulatory authority allows for necessary guidance to ensure adequate employment and benefits protection and prevent abuse of this section. SEC. 102. COORDINATION WITH REFUND PROVISION.

Section 45A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be treated as a credit provision of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 enacted before January 1, 1978.

SEC. 103. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS.

Section 38 is amended to include the family leave credit under section 45A.

SEC. 104. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The amendments apply to family leave starting 90 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 201. CORPORATE ESTIMATED TAX PROVISIONS. Increase in Estimated Tax under the Corporate Estimated Tax Provisions involves amending subsection (d) of section 6655 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to raise the required installments to 100 percent from 91 percent. Conforming amendments are also made to ensure consistency in the tax code. The required installments percentages are as follows: 1st - 254, 2nd - 504, 3rd - 754, 4th - 100. Clause (i) of section 6655(e)(3)(A) of the Code is amended to change the percentage from 91 percent to 100 percent. Additionally, there are modifications to the periods for applying annualization in section 6655(e)(2)(A) of the Code. The clause amends section 6655(e)(3)(A) of the Code by changing the time periods for annualization. Subclauses in subparagraph (A)(i) are adjusted by substituting different time frames. The clause amends section 6655(e)(3)(A) of the Code by changing time periods for annualization. Subclauses in subparagraph (A)(i) are adjusted by substituting different time frames, with elections under clause (i) or (ii) effective for the taxable year made on or before the date required for the payment of the second installment. The amendments made by this section apply to any installment due date occurring more than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act.
